Package com.peterphi.std.types

Class StorageSize

java.lang.Object
com.peterphi.std.types.StorageSize
All Implemented Interfaces:
Serializable, Comparable<StorageSize>
public final class StorageSize extends Object implements Comparable<StorageSize>, Serializable

Note: this class has a natural ordering that is inconsistent with equals.

Represents an amount of space in a given unit
Internally the amount of storage this object refers to is stored in bits. Any time getAmount() or getBytes() is called this value is converted to the necessary unit

Users are discouraged from using getAmount() unless a rounded value is acceptable (which it rarely is). In most circumstances users are recommended to use getDecimalAmount()

See Also:

  • Field Details

    • ZERO

      public static final StorageSize ZERO

  • Constructor Details

    • StorageSize

      public StorageSize(BigInteger amount, StorageUnit unit)
      Creates a new StorageSize where the value is equal to the provided value
      If the unit is in BITS then any fractional bytes resulting from the conversion will be discarded (e.g. passing 9 bits will result in 1 byte)
      Parameters:
      amount - the amount component of the space this StorageSize should represent
      unit - the unit that amount is expressed in

    • StorageSize

      public StorageSize(BigDecimal amount, StorageUnit unit)
      Creates a new StorageSize where the value is an approximation of the provided value
      Since this is an approximation some information may be lost. This method converts the amount to a number of bytes, then converts it to an integer using the toBigInteger() method of BigDecimal, so information loss should be minimised
      Parameters:
      amount - the amount component of the space this StorageSize should represent
      unit - the unit that amount is expressed in. If the unit is BITS then any fractional bits will be ignored (i.e. identical to calling the BigInteger constructor with amount.toBigInteger())

    • StorageSize

      protected StorageSize(StorageUnit unit, BigInteger bits)
      Internal constructor. Should not be exposed to users
      Parameters:
      unit - the unit the user would like to see their StorageSize in by default
      bytes - the number of bytes this StorageSize represents

    • StorageSize

      public StorageSize(long amount, StorageUnit unit)

  • Method Details

    • getBytes

      public BigInteger getBytes()
      Return the number of bytes this StorageSize represents
      This method may result in information being lost (e.g. partial bits). Users are encouraged to use the getBits method if this loss is unacceptable
      Returns:
      the number of bytes represented by this object (determined by diving the number of bits by 8 and then rounding the result)

    • getBits

      public BigInteger getBits()
      The number of bits represented by this object
      Returns:
      the number of bits represented by this object

    • getUnit

      public StorageUnit getUnit()
      The unit which this Storage Size should be expressed by default
      Returns:
      the unit which this Storage Size should be expressed by default

    • getDecimalAmount

      public BigDecimal getDecimalAmount()
      Converts the size of this StorageSize to another unit, returning the result as a real number (using the BigDecimal type)
      Uses the default representation unit for this type
      The calculations may result in minimal loss of precision, however this is unavoidable.
      Returns:
      a real number approximation (which will be more accurate than getAmount() which only deals with integers)

    • getDecimalAmount

      public BigDecimal getDecimalAmount(StorageUnit unit)
      Converts the size of this StorageSize to another unit, returning the result as a real number (using the BigDecimal type)
      The calculations may result in minimal loss of precision, however this is unavoidable.
      Parameters:
      unit - the unit to use (instead of the default StorageSize unit)
      Returns:
      an approximation of the (which will be more accurate than getAmount(unit) which only deals with integers)

    • getAmount

      @Deprecated public BigInteger getAmount()
      Deprecated.
      Converts the size of this StorageSize to another unit, rounding the result to an integer
      Uses the default representation unit for this type
      This method may result in the loss of information (due to rounding). If precision is required then getDecimalAmount() should be used
      Returns:
      the size (as an integer) in the default unit for this StorageSize.

    • getAmount

      public BigInteger getAmount(StorageUnit unit)
      Converts the size of this StorageSize to another unit, rounding the result to an integer
      This method may result in the loss of information (due to rounding). If precision is required then getDecimalAmount(unit) should be used
      Parameters:
      unit - the unit to use (instead of the default StorageSize unit)
      Returns:
      the size (as an integer) in the provided unit.

    • isZero

      public boolean isZero()
      Determines whether this StorageSize represents zero (which is the same in any unit)
      Returns:
      true if the number of bits represented by this object is exactly Zero, otherwise false

    • compareTo

      public int compareTo(StorageSize that)
      Performs a comparison based on the number of bits represented
      Since this class has a natural ordering that is inconsistent with equals, this method may return 0 where equals would not return 0 - since this compares based on bits but equals tests based on the unit+amount
      Specified by:
      compareTo in interface Comparable<StorageSize>
      Parameters:
      that - some other storage amount
      See Also:
      • Comparable.compareTo(java.lang.Object)

    • compareTo

      public int compareTo(long amount, StorageUnit unit)
      Performs a comparison based on the number of bits represented
      Since this class has a natural ordering that is inconsistent with equals, this method may return 0 where equals would not return 0 - since this compares based on bits but equals tests based on the unit+amount
      Parameters:
      amount - the number of units for this amount
      unit - the unit that amount should be expressed in
      See Also:
      • Comparable.compareTo(java.lang.Object)
